then shall our names, Familiar in his mouth as household words Harry the king, Bedford and Exeter, Warwick and Talbot, Salisbury and Gloucester, Be in their flowing cups freshly remember'd. And this story shall the good man teach his son; And Crispin Crispian shall ne'er go by, From this day to the ending of the world, But we in it shall be remember'd;
[Looking at the Double Ds]
We few, we happy few, we band of brothers; For he to-day that sheds his blood with me Shall be my brother.
[Looking back at the rest of the platoon]

And gentlemen in England now a-bed Shall think themselves accursed they were not here, And hold their manhoods cheap whiles any speaks who fought with us upon Saint Crispin's day". That enough Drill Sergeant?

[Quietly]
Yes, Benitez. Good.

[chanting]
Hamlet's mother, she's the queen / Buys it in the final scene / Drinks a glass of funky wine / Now she's Satan's Valentine.
All I know is, the choices we make dictate the life we lead. "To thine own self be true."
It says here that you're from Detroit. What part?
The part you drive through doing 85.
Been there.
[Talking about Shakespeare to the class]
He wrote plays. Plays...? You know, like TV without the box.
[reading about why they joined the Army]

There's these woods behind our trailer park. This old guy lives in the woods there. Everybody in town swore he was crazy. He showed me how to hunt, and how to be real quiet, and how to listen. He said he had seen everythin' in the world he wanted to see, and he ain't never wanted to leave those woods. Well, me and my daddy got laid off at the paper mill, and whilst I spent about five months watchin' TV with my brothers, I kept thinkin' of what the old man said. Finally, I decided that I did want to see more of the world, and what was behind that trailer park. And that's why I joined up.

I liked livin' with my aunt, Mavis, in Chicago the best. But last summer, my mother, Ruthie, came back and we drove to Atlanta. She said, "We don't have to stay long," but then she met a man, and they take off. I waited around for a while, waitin' for her to come back, but everybody keep sayin', "Just go on home." I don't know where that is. So I take the bus to Cleaveland and spend two days starin' at the poster behind the driver sayin', "Be all you can be." So I think about that for a week, and think I gotta be somewhere, so here I am.

In my crib, there ain't never been a time where we eat, sleep, or nothin'. Y'know, everybody just run around crazy. Half the time, I don't even know who we are. I must be the only person in the world who joined the army so he'd know exactly what time he'd be eating lunch.
I wanted to learn a new trade.

[voice over, while Bill is reading a letter from him]
Dear Mr. Rago, Thanks for all your letters. And I don't know what you and Captain Murdoch wrote to the warden but it sure worked. Because I might be getting out of here soon. Just wanted you to know, I'm reading Othello. Imagine that. Mr. Shakespeare writing about a black man way back then, and a soldier too. Prison librarian says I'm the first to check out Shakespeare in 16 years. She asked me if I was interested in signing up for some college classes. I told her if they had a few teachers like you, I just might. Well, Mr. Rago, like Hamlet says, the rest is silence. Sincerely, Nathanial T Hobbs.
I'd rather be a Double D than a swinger from the ugly tree, you fat pig.
Hi. I'm Bill Rago. I've never taught before and you've never thought before. So good luck to all of us.
I ain't never gonna hit my kids.
You seen my green socks?
We all got green socks.
[another recruit is trying to bang a rhythm on his desk]
Give him time, give him time. He's a white boy.
[Melvin is reading a passage from HAMLET in a monotone voice]
Melvin, read the rest of it when you come out of the coma.
[reading Hamlet]
Bill, are you gonna translate this?
Why? It's in English.

[about reading their essay]
All right, who wants to start?
[no reply]
Nobody?
[snickers]
I thought this was the volunteer army...
Write... why you're here.
This is where they told us to be.
No, no. Write about the magical twist of fate that prompted you to gravitate towards this institute of imbeciles.

[confused]
What?

[very nonchalantly]
Write why you joined the Army.
Now what's a Double D?
The whole fort calls us Double Ds.
Yeah - dumb as dog shit.

[reads referral]
Captain Tom Murdoch.
Captain Murdoch's not at the A.E.C. Captain Murdoch's at the A.R.C

[fumbling to write down directions]
A.R.C., A.E.C.

[Walks up to Rago]
You lookin' for Captain Murdoch?
Yeah.
The A.E.C. is building 2310. You want building 4475.
Look, here's what you do. You go right here. Take another right at the P.X. Go half a click 'til you see the D.P.T.M. Center. Then take a left.

[writing furiously]
P.M., P.X.
If you hit the R.F.P.C., you've gone too far.
[returns to post]

[reviewing notes]
D.P.T.M., R.F.P.C.
[pause]
Can I buy a vowel?
Hey, excuse me, sir. I'm lookin' for the base chapel
Base chapel?
Yeah.
Go back around the curve 'til you reach the P.X. Ya hang a right. Ya come to that line A.P.C.s, ya turn left. Go half a click, ya come to the R.F.P.C. building. It's right around the back. Got it?

[confused]
Yeah.
[Rago tells Leroy about Leon Battista Alberti, the archetypal "Renaissance Man."]
But you know what I remember most about him?
No.
They said that he could stand, with his feet together like this, and spring straight over a man's head.

[laughs]
Really?
If Leon Battista Alberti couldn't have done that, I wouldn't have remembered a thing about him.
So, wait... he was sort of like a smart jock, wasn't he?
That's right.
Now there's an oxymoron, isn't it?
You got it.
GO NAVY.
[Bill writes "oxymoron" on the board]
You can't say that. That is a diss. I ain't no ox moron.
No, no, no not ox moron, schmuck; oxymoron.
